{{WMOG-header|Leucanthemum vulgare}}{{WMOG-header|Leucanthemum vulgare}}__NOTOC__{{Hortibox|Oxeye daisy | Image = Leucanthemum-vulgare crop.jpg | Binomial = Leucanthemum vulgare | Genus = | Family = Asteraceae | Variety = | Type = herbaceous perennial | Sun = full sun | Water = | Soil = | USDA Hardiness Zone = | Sunset Zone = | Propagation = | Pruning season = | Pruning tolerance = | Forcing = | Transplant = | Pest issues = | Disease issues = | Bloom season = spring | Fruit season = | Sowing methods = | Harvest = | Storage = | Weediness = | Pollination = | Seed Dispersal = | Germination Time = | Germination Signal = | Ripe Seed = | Seed Banking = | Vegetative Spread = | Allelopathy = | Group = | Sowing time = | Days to germination = | Days to baby = | Days to maturity = | Bolting = | Flat cropping = | Planting depth = | Plant spacing = | Row spacing = | Seed collection = | Height and spread = | Root = | Growth rate = | Shade cast = | Underplanting = | Toxicity and edibility = | Patent= | Hybrid type= }} The '''oxeye daisy''' (''Leucanthemum vulgare'', syn. ''Chrysanthemum leucanthemum'') also known as the '''marguerite''' is a widespread flowering plant native to Europe and the temperate regions of Asia. It is one of a number of plants to be called by the common name daisy. It is also sometimes called moon daisy or dog daisy.
==Description== It is a perennial prostrate herb with small flower head (not larger than 5 cm) that consists of about 20 white ray flowers and numerous yellow disc flowers, growing on the end of the stem. The stem is mostly unbranched and sprouts laterally from a creeping rootstock.
The leaves are darkgreen on both sides. The basal and middle leaves are petiolate, obovate to spoon-shaped, and serrate to dentate. The upper leaves are shorter, sessile and borne along the stem.
It produces an abundant number of flat seeds without pappus. It spreads also vegetatively by rooting underground stems.
==Growing Conditions==
<!--sun, soil, etc.-->
==Varieties==
<!--general discussion or bulleted list-->
==Uses== The oxeye daisy is a typical meadow flower, growing in a variety of plant communities such as dry fields, meadows, but also under scrubs, open-canopy forests and waste places. It thrives in a wide range of conditions and prefers heavy and damp soils. It was introduced in parts of North America, Australia and New Zealand, where it is now a common weed displacing native plant species in some areas. It is difficult to control or eradicate, since a new plant can regenerate from rhizome fragments. However, in North Carolina it is planted on roadsides by the highway department.<ref>"Wildflowers Find Favor With Highway Gardeners" article by Felicity Barringer in the New York Times August 29, 2007</ref>
The un-opened buds can be marinated and used in a similar way to capers. <ref>[http://www.wildfoods.ca/products-vegetables-ox-eyedaisycapers.html Ox-eye Daisy Capers] at [http://www.wildfoods.ca/index.html Forbes wild foods]. Retrieved December 12, 2006.</ref> The game "He loves me, he loves me not" ("effeuiller la marguerite" (in French)) is associated with this flower.
==Maintenance==
<!--discuss any special maintenance concerns, such as pruning, transplanting, monitoring, etc.-->
==Propagation==
<!--discuss propagation-->
==Harvest==
<!--Discuss harvesting and storage-->
==Pests and Diseases==
==References== <references/> *{{cite book | author=Blanchan, Neltje | title=Wild Flowers Worth Knowing | year=2005 | publisher= Project Gutenberg Literary Archive Foundation}}

revision.text:
{{WMOG-header|Linaria vulgaris}}__NOTOC__{{Hortibox|Toadflax | Image = Linaria vulgaris 20050825 976.jpg | Binomial = Linaria vulgaris | Genus = | Family = Plantaginaceae | Variety = | Type = herbaceous | Sun = | Water = | Soil = | USDA Hardiness Zone = | Sunset Zone = | Propagation = | Pruning season = | Pruning tolerance = | Forcing = | Transplant = | Pest issues = | Disease issues = | Bloom season = | Fruit season = | Sowing methods = | Harvest = | Storage = | Weediness = | Pollination = | Seed Dispersal = | Germination Time = | Germination Signal = | Ripe Seed = | Seed Banking = | Vegetative Spread = | Allelopathy = | Group = | Sowing time = | Days to germination = | Days to baby = | Days to maturity = | Bolting = | Flat cropping = | Planting depth = | Plant spacing = | Row spacing = | Seed collection = | Height and spread = | Root = | Growth rate = | Shade cast = | Underplanting = | Toxicity and edibility = | Patent= | Hybrid type= }} '''''Linaria vulgaris''''' ('''Common Toadflax'''<ref>Natural History Museum: [http://flood.nhm.ac.uk/jobj/java/runjava.jobj?java=ctol.CTOLServer&method=printNamePage&accountref=987&NAMEID=7673 ''Linaria vulgaris'']</ref><ref name=blamey>Blamey, M. & Grey-Wilson, C. (1989). ''Flora of Britain and Northern Europe''. ISBN 0-340-40170-2</ref>) is a low growing plant native to most of Europe and northern Asia, from the United Kingdom south to Spain in the west, and east to eastern Siberia and western China.<ref name=flora>''Flora Europaea'': [http://rbg-web2.rbge.org.uk/cgi-bin/nph-readbtree.pl/feout?FAMILY_XREF=&GENUS_XREF=Linaria+&SPECIES_XREF=vulgaris&TAXON_NAME_XREF=&RANK= ''Linaria vulgaris'']</ref><ref name=grin>Germplasm Resources Information Network: [http://www.ars-grin.gov/cgi-bin/npgs/html/taxon.pl?102290 ''Linaria vulgaris'']</ref>
''Linaria acutiloba'' Fisch. ex Rchb. is a synonym.<ref name=flora/> Because this plant grows as a weed, it has acquired a large number of local colloquial names, including brideweed, bridewort, butter and eggs (but see ''[[../Lotus corniculatus/]]''), butter haycocks, bread and butter, bunny haycocks, bunny mouths, calf's snout, Continental weed, dead men's bones, devil's flax, devil's flower, doggies, dragon bushes, eggs and bacon (but see ''[[../Lotus corniculatus/]]''), eggs and butter, false flax, flaxweed, fluellen (but see ''[[../Kichxia/]]''), gallweed, gallwort, imprudent lawyer, impudent lawyer, Jacob's ladder (but see ''[[../Polemonium/]]''), lion's mouth, monkey flower (but see ''[[../Mimulus/]]''), North American ramsted, rabbit flower, rancid, ransted, snapdragon (but see ''[[../Antirrhinum/]]''), wild flax, wild snapdragon, wild tobacco (but see ''[[Nicotiana]]''), yellow rod, yellow toadflax.<ref name=mabey/>
[[Image:Linaria_vulgaris.jpg|left|thumb|''Linaria vulgaris'' in a meadow]] The plant is widespread on ruderal spots, along roads, in dunes, and on disturbed and cultivated land.<ref name=blamey/> It has escaped from cultivation in North America where it is a common naturalised weed of roadsides and poor soils; it is listed as an invasive species in several U.S. states and Canadian provinces.<ref name=grin/><ref>Alberta Invasive Plants: [http://www.invasiveplants.ab.ca/Downloads/CommonToadflax.pdf Common Toadflax] (pdf file)</ref><ref>Nathaniel Lord Britton and Hon. Addison Brown, ''An Illustrated Flora of the Northern United States and Canada'', Dover Publications, [[1913]], [[1970]]. ISBN 0-486-22642-5 vol 3, p. 177</ref>
==Description== It is a perennial plant with short spreading roots, erect to decumbent stems 15–90 cm high, with fine, threadlike, glaucous blue-green leaves 2-6 cm long and 1-5 mm broad. The flowers are similar to those of the snapdragon, 25-33 mm long, pale yellow except for the lower lip which is orange, borne in dense terminal racemes from mid summer to mid autumn. The fruit is a globose capsule 5-11 mm long and 5-7 mm broad, containing numerous small seeds.<ref name=blamey/>
Because the flower is largely closed by its underlip, pollination requires strong insects such as bees and bumblebees (''[[../Bombus/]]'' species).<ref name=blamey/>
==Growing Conditions== The plant requires ample drainage, but is otherwise adaptable to a variety of conditions.
==Varieties==
<!--general discussion or bulleted list-->
==Uses== While most commonly found as a weed, toadflax is sometimes cultivated for cut flowers, which are long-lasting in the vase. Like snapdragons (''[[../Antirrhinum/]]''), they are often grown in children's gardens for the "snapping" flowers which can be made to "talk" be squeezing them at the base of the corolla.<ref name=mabey>Mabey, R. (1996). ''Flora Britannica''. Sinclair-Stevenson ISBN 1-85619-377-2</ref>
==Maintenance==
<!--discuss any special maintenance concerns, such as pruning, transplanting, monitoring, etc.-->
==Propagation==
<!--discuss propagation-->
==Harvest==
<!--Discuss harvesting and storage-->
==Pests and Diseases== The plant is foodplant for a large number of insects such as the [[w:Sweet-Gale Moth]] (''Acronicta euphorbiae''), [[w:Mouse Moth]] (''Amphipyra tragopoginis''), [[w:Silver Y]] (''Autographa gamma''), ''[[w:Calophasia lunula]]'', [[w:Gorgone Checkerspot]] (''Charidryas gorgone carlota''), [[w:Toadflax Pug ]] (''Eupithecia linariata''), [[w:Satyr Pug]] (''Eupithecia satyrata''), ''[[w:Falseuncaria ruficiliana]]'', [[w:Bog Fritillary]] (''Proclossiana eunomia eunomia''), ''[[w:Pyrrhia umbra]]'', [[w:Brown Rustic]] (''Rusina ferruginea''), and ''[[w:Stenoptilia bipunctidactyla]].
==References== <references/>

revision.text:
{{WMOG-header|Lonicera maackii}}{{WMOG-header|Lonicera maackii}}{{Hortibox|Amur Honeysuckle | Image = LoniceraMaackiiFlowers3.jpg | Binomial = Lonicera maackii | Genus = | Family = Caprifoliaceae | Variety = | Type = shrub | Sun = | Water = | Soil = | USDA Hardiness Zone = | Sunset Zone = | Propagation = | Pruning season = | Pruning tolerance = | Forcing = | Transplant = | Pest issues = | Disease issues = | Bloom season = | Fruit season = | Sowing methods = | Harvest = | Storage = | Weediness = weedy, invasive in some regions | Pollination = | Seed Dispersal = | Germination Time = | Germination Signal = | Ripe Seed = | Seed Banking = | Vegetative Spread = | Allelopathy = | Group = | Sowing time = | Days to germination = | Days to baby = | Days to maturity = | Bolting = | Flat cropping = | Planting depth = | Plant spacing = | Row spacing = | Seed collection = | Height and spread = | Root = | Growth rate = | Shade cast = | Underplanting = | Toxicity and edibility = | Patent= | Hybrid type= }} '''''Lonicera maackii''''' ('''Amur Honeysuckle''' or '''Bush Honeysuckle''') is a species of honeysuckle in the family Caprifoliaceae, native to temperate Asia in northern and western China (south to Yunnan), Mongolia, Japan (central and northern Honshū, rare), Korea, and southeastern Russia (Primorsky Krai).<ref name=grin>Germplasm Resources Information Network: [http://www.ars-grin.gov/cgi-bin/npgs/html/taxon.pl?22596 ''Lonicera maackii'']</ref> It is listed as an endangered species in Japan.<ref name=japan>Ministry of the Environment (Japan): [http://www.biodic.go.jp/english/rdb/red_plants.csv Red List of Threatened Plants of Japan (excel spreadsheet)]</ref><ref name=redlistjp>Red Data Book (Japan): [http://www.rdbplants.jp/RDB/map/sp-5/2/5281.htm ''Lonicera maackii''] (in Japanese, with map; [http://translate.google.com/translate?hl=en&sl=ja&u=http://www.rdbplants.jp/RDB/map/sp-5/2/5281.htm&sa=X&oi=translate&resnum=10& google translation])</ref> It has escaped from cultivation and become naturalised in New Zealand and the eastern United States; in the forests of the latter, it has become an important invasive species.<ref name=usfs/>
The common name Amur Honeysuckle comes from the Amur River which is the world's eighth longest river. This river forms the border between the Russian Far East and Manchuria in China. L. maackii is native to the area surrounding this river. The species name maackii is derived from Richard Maack, a 19th century Russian naturalist.<ref name=osu/>
==Description== [[Image:LoniceraMaackii5.jpg|left|thumb|Foliage and fruit in autumn]] It is a deciduous large shrub growing to 6 m tall with stems up to 10 cm diameter. The leaves are oppositely arranged, 5–9 cm long and 2–4 cm broad, with an entire margin, and with at least some rough hairs on them. The flowers are produced in pairs, commonly with several pairs grouped together in clusters; they are 2 cm long, two-lipped, white later turning yellow or light orange in colour; flowering is from mid spring to early summer. The fruit is a bright red to black semi-translucent berry 2–6 mm diameter containing numerous small seeds; they ripen in autumn, and are eaten by birds, which disperse the seeds in their droppings. It is fast growing and favours shady habitats such as the forest understory, neglected urban areas, and fence rows. It can form extremely dense thickets.<ref name=rhs>Huxley, A., ed. (1992). ''New RHS Dictionary of Gardening''. Macmillan ISBN 0-333-47494-5.</ref><ref name=mp>Missouriplants: [http://www.missouriplants.com/Whiteopp/Lonicera_maackii_page.html ''Lonicera maackii'']</ref><ref name=io>Invasive.org: [http://www.invasive.org/weeds/asian/lonicera.pdf ''Lonicera'' species (pdf file)]</ref>
==Growing Conditions==
<!--sun, soil, etc.-->
==Varieties==
<!--general discussion or bulleted list-->
==Uses== [[File:LoniceraMackii4.jpg|right|220px|thumb|''Lonicera maackii'' planted as a [[hedge]].]] It is grown as an ornamental plant for its attractive flowers, and also as a hedge. A number of cultivars have been selected for garden use, including 'Erubescens' with pink flowers, and 'Rem Red' with erect habit.<ref name=rhs/>
The flowers are sometimes used by children, who remove the blossom by hand, and pull off the bottom to suck out the sweet nectar in the centre. The red berries are mildly poisonous to humans and should not be eaten.
==Invasiveness== Spread of this plant is illegal or controlled in some areas of the United States due to its well documented invasive character.<ref name=usfs>[http://www.na.fs.fed.us/fhp/invasive_plants/weeds/amur-honeysuckle.pdf USA Forest Service Weed of the Week Fact Sheet (pdf file)]</ref><ref name= prime>[http://sain.utk.edu/invasives/species44.shtml Annotated Bibliography of primary research on invasive qualities of L. maackii in the USA: National Biological Information Infrastructure]</ref><ref name=uconn>[http://www.hort.uconn.edu/Plants/l/lonmaa/lonmaa1.html University of Connecticut Plant Database: ''L. maackii'']</ref><ref name=osu>[http://hcs.osu.edu/pocketgardener/source/description/lo_ackii.html Ohio State University Pocket Gardener: ''L. maackii'']</ref><ref name=mp/> It is listed as a "invasive, banned" species in Connecticut, "prohibited" in Massachusetts, and a "Class B noxious weed" in Vermont.<ref name=plants>[http://plants.usda.gov/java/profile?symbol=LOMA6 USDA PLANTS DATABASE: ''L. maackii'']</ref> It is also officially listed as an invasive species by government agencies in Wisconsin and Tennessee.<ref name=plants/>
This plant is adaptable and successful in a wide range of conditions. In the United States, Amur honeysuckle was once planted to control erosion, and as hedges. It spread quickly as birds dispersed the seeds, and was soon naturalised. Notably, in deciduous forest understories of the eastern United States it forms dense growths with thick canopies that shade out native shrubs, young trees, and wild flowers.<ref name=uconn/><ref name=prime/><ref name=osu/><ref name=usfs/><ref name=mp/> Uncontrolled, these growths create a near monoculture of Amur Honeysuckle.<ref name=uconn/><ref name=prime/><ref name=osu/><ref name= usfs /><ref name= mp/> This species poses a serious threat not only to the diversity of the ecosystems which they invade but also to forest regeneration itself.<ref name=uconn/><ref name=prime/><ref name=osu/><ref name=usfs/><ref name=mp/>
Due to the invasive nature of this species and the ecological threat it possess it may be inadvisable to cultivate this plant in climates similar to those found where this species has become invasive (e.g. eastern United States).<ref name=prime/> It has been suggested that existing specimens found outside of their native range in east Asia should be removed and replaced with alternative non-invasive species.<ref name=osu/> Possible alternative fast growing, shade tolerant, deciduous shrubs include ''[[../Calycanthus floridus/]]'', ''[[../Cornus mas/]]'', ''[[../Cornus sericea/]]'', ''[[../Forsythia/]]'' hybrids, ''[[../Hydrangea/]]'' spp., ''[[../Syringa vulgaris/]]'', ''[[../Viburnum cassinoides/]]'', ''[[../Viburnum dentatum/]]'', ''[[../Viburnum dilatatum/]]'', ''[[../Viburnum opulus/]]'' , ''[[../Viburnum prunifolium/]]'', ''[[../Viburnum trilobum/]]'', ''[[../Weigela florida/]]''.<ref name= osu />
==Maintenance==
<!--discuss any special maintenance concerns, such as pruning, transplanting, monitoring, etc.-->
==Control== Honeysuckle can be controlled by cutting, flaming, or burning the plant to root level and repeating on two-week increments until nutrient reserves in the roots are depleted. To ensure eradication newly cut stumps should be treated with herbicide. Control through prescribed burning has been found to be most effective during the seed dispersal phase (late summer, early fall).<ref name=usfs/> Honeysuckle can also be controlled through annual applications of glyphosate which thoroughly soak the leaves, or through grubbing of the shallowly rooted young plants. Both of these methods are only practical if high labour costs and soil damage are not of concern.
==Propagation==
<!--discuss propagation-->
==Harvest==
<!--Discuss harvesting and storage-->
==Pests and Diseases==
==References== <references/>

''This is my sandbox, I'm just trying some stuff out. This isn't an article.''
[[Image:Wikibookqsjapanese-projectl.png|center|Wikibooks - Quick Start Japanese (logo image)]]
----
{| align="center" | style="background:blue; color:white" | '''Before you begin''' |- | [[/Introduction|Introduction]] |- | [[/Learn to read, it's easy!|Learn to read, it's easy!]] |- | style="background:green; color:white" | '''Being friendly''' |- | [[/Introductions|Introductions]] |- | [[/Greetings|Greetings]] |- | [[/Saying bye|Saying bye]] |- | style="background:orange; color:white" | '''Finding out what things are''' |- | [[/Basic questions|Basic questions]] |- | [[/Asking to know more|Asking to know more]] |- | style="background:purple; color:white" | '''Describing things''' |- | [[/Things you can see|Things you can see]] |- | [[/Emotions you have|Emotions you have]] |- | style="background:teal; color:white" | '''Requesting things''' |- | [[/Things you want|Things you want]] |- | [[/Actions you want to do|Actions you want to do]] |}

[[Image:Wikibookqsjapanese-projectl.png|250px]]
So you want to learn Japanese in less time than it takes you to learn how to play a complex board game? Well, that might not be possible. However, if you dig in and try hard you might be able to learn the basics faster than you think.
== What this is and what this is not == This is not a complete guide to the Japanese language. This is not every possible correct way of saying each and every word. Those kind of books are useful but take a lot of mental investment on the part of the reader. This book is simply a step above a phrase book. This book is for those who want to jump in quick and learn from that moment forward. This book will let you know the basic phrases and words in an intuitive "plug and play" kind of way that will let you learn even more on your own. Remember this is just a quick introduction to a very complex language. Don't sweat the grammar, just memorize the provided text. This book uses hiragana (a Japanese alphabet) to write the sounds of Japanese, it is easy to learn and you can do that next. And there is even a way for you to cheat and not learn, if you really don't want to. So even if you don't want to do learn a Japanese alphabet, click next and see if you change your mind. You should be up and communicating in no time! Goodluck!
'''Next: [[/Learn to read, it's easy!|Learn to read, it's easy!]]

== Welcome! ==
{{{1|Welcome, {{PAGENAME}}!}}} {| style="background:white; border:1px solid #abd5f5;; padding:0px; border-spacing:0px; color: #000000;" ! style="background:#d0e5f5; color: #000000;" | [[Wikibooks:Welcome|Getting started]] with Wikibooks |- | style="padding:5px;" | * Wikibooks is a collection of open-source textbooks. Find out [[WB:WIW|what this means]]. * To sign your name (on talk pages), use four tildes, like this: ~~~~ * For help in using the wiki, see [[Using Wikibooks]]. * For information about the community here, see [[Wikibooks Community]]. * Explore, [[Wikibooks:Be bold|be bold]], and have fun! |}
Come introduce yourself at the [[WB:SLN|new users]] page. If you have any questions, you can ask there or contact me personally.--'''Whiteknight''' ([[User:Whiteknight|Page]]) ([[User talk:Whiteknight|Talk]]) 16:32, 18 December 2007 (UTC)

Thanks for adding a bit to the book! I hope there's more to come!

page.title: User talk:Nesnad/sandbox/Learn to read, it's easy!

revision.text:
OK. So you are thinking ''I want to communicate! I don't want to learn boring foreign letter-shape things!!'' Stop right there! Learning one of the basic Japanese alphabets is not that hard. You can pull out a note book and write each character over and over for about 20 minutes and you should have the basics. No? You want to get started faster than that? Well, leave this window open and read the other lessons in another browser window. Use this window to help you decode the phrases. That will help you start memorizing if you are in too much of a hurry to memorize these now. Why not provide the text in roman letters? Because it's not hard to learn a basic foreign alphabet and you'll soon realize that the key to "jumping in" so to speak, is to be thinking '''in''' the target language. Still haven't convinced you? OK. Heres the cheat button. Just hover your browser cursor over this icon [[Image:Blue ball.png|10px|reading of Japanese here!]] and see what it is in English letters. You really should learn the Japanese letters though. So if you haven't already; learn hiragana it isn't that hard.
* basic hiragana: <big>[[wikt:あ|あ]]</big> <small>(a)</small>, <big>[[wikt:い|い]]</big> <small>(i)</small>, <big>[[wikt:う|う]]</big> <small>(u)</small>, <big>[[wikt:え|え]]</big> <small>(e)</small>, <big>[[wikt:お|お]]</big> <small>(o)</small>, <big>[[wikt:か|か]]</big> <small>(ka)</small>, <big>[[wikt:き|き]]</big> <small>(ki)</small>, <big>[[wikt:く|く]]</big> <small>(ku)</small>, <big>[[wikt:け|け]]</big> <small>(ke)</small>, <big>[[wikt:こ|こ]]</big> <small>(ko)</small>, <big>[[wikt:さ|さ]]</big> <small>(sa)</small>, <big>[[wikt:し|し]]</big> <small>(shi)</small>, <big>[[wikt:す|す]]</big> <small>(su)</small>, <big>[[wikt:せ|せ]]</big> <small>(se)</small>, <big>[[wikt:そ|そ]]</big> <small>(so)</small>, <big>[[wikt:た|た]]</big> <small>(ta)</small>, <big>[[wikt:ち|ち]]</big> <small>(chi)</small>, <big>[[wikt:つ|つ]]</big> <small>(tsu)</small>, <big>[[wikt:て|て]]</big> <small>(te)</small>, <big>[[wikt:と|と]]</big> <small>(to)</small>, <big>[[wikt:な|な]]</big> <small>(na)</small>, <big>[[wikt:に|に]]</big> <small>(ni)</small>, <big>[[wikt:ぬ|ぬ]]</big> <small>(nu)</small>, <big>[[wikt:ね|ね]]</big> <small>(ne)</small>, <big>[[wikt:の|の]]</big> <small>(no)</small>, <big>[[wikt:は|は]]</big> <small>(ha)</small>, <big>[[wikt:ひ|ひ]]</big> <small>(hi)</small>, <big>[[wikt:ふ|ふ]]</big> <small>(fu)</small>, <big>[[wikt:へ|へ]]</big> <small>(he)</small>, <big>[[wikt:ほ|ほ]]</big> <small>(ho)</small>, <big>[[wikt:ま|ま]]</big> <small>(ma)</small>, <big>[[wikt:み|み]]</big> <small>(mi)</small>, <big>[[wikt:む|む]]</big> <small>(mu)</small>, <big>[[wikt:め|め]]</big> <small>(me)</small>, <big>[[wikt:も|も]]</big> <small>(mo)</small>, <big>[[wikt:や|や]]</big> <small>(ya)</small>, <big>[[wikt:ゆ|ゆ]]</big> <small>(yu)</small>, <big>[[wikt:よ|よ]]</big> <small>(yo)</small>, <big>[[wikt:ら|ら]]</big> <small>(ra)</small>, <big>[[wikt:り|り]]</big> <small>(ri)</small>, <big>[[wikt:る|る]]</big> <small>(ru)</small>, <big>[[wikt:れ|れ]]</big> <small>(re)</small>, <big>[[wikt:ろ|ろ]]</big> <small>(ro)</small>, <big>[[wikt:わ|わ]]</big> <small>(wa)</small>, <big>[[wikt:を|を]]</big> <small>(wo)</small>, <big>[[wikt:ん|ん]]</big> <small>(n)</small>
* You should also know:
That if you add a ” to K row sounds (such as か) it becomes a G. <big>か</big> <small>(ka)</small> becomes <big>が</big> <small>(ga)</small>
If you add a ” to S row sounds (such as さ) it becomes a Z. <big>さ</big> <small>(sa)</small> becomes <big>ざ</big> <small>(za)</small>
In the same way, add a ” to T row sounds (such as た) it becomes a D. <big>た</big> <small>(ta)</small> becomes <big>だ</big> <small>(da)</small>
Also add a ” to H row sounds (such as は) it becomes a B. <big>は</big> <small>(ha)</small> becomes <big>ば</big> <small>(ba)</small>
Finally a new one! Add ° to H row sounds (such as は) it becomes a P. <big>は</big> <small>(ha)</small> becomes <big>ぱ</big> <small>(pa)</small>
* Three small exceptions <big>じ</big> <small>(ji)</small>, <big>ぢ</big> <small>(ji)</small> and <big>づ</big> <small>(zu)</small>
That's it! Not too hard. There are other ways to tweak these letters and a whole other set of letters plus Chinese characters. Don't worry about those for now. Now it's on to learning to communicate!
'''Next:''' [[empty link]]

Greeting people isn't that hard. It just depends on what time of day it is. In the morning Johnny would say:
[[Image:Qsjapaneseicon-man01.png|left]] {| align="left" | style="background:blue; color:white" | '''Johnny''' |- | おはようございます [[Image:Blue ball.png|10px|ohayougozaimasu]] |- | ''Good morning'' |- |} [[Image:Wikibooksqsjapanese1-snd004.ogg|left]]
Now lets time travel into the future a little bit. In the afternoon Mary would say...
[[Image:Qsjapaneseicon-woman.png|right]] {| align="right" | style="background:red; color:white" | '''Mary''' |- | こんにちは [[Image:Blue ball.png|10px|konnichiWA]] |- | ''Good afternoon'' (hello) |- | ***<small> '''WARNING:''' <big>は</big> is special and pronounced </small> |- | <small>like a WA sound. Also, don't fall into the </small> |- | <small>bad habit of saying KAN for the start. </small> |- | <small>Its KON. OK. Go back to using non-English </small> |- | <small>letters to read Japanese. </small> |} [[Image:Wikibooksqsjapanese1-snd005.ogg|right]]
Yawn... it's getting late, did we get in the time machine again? It's evening!
[[Image:Qsjapaneseicon-man01.png|left]] {| align="left" | style="background:blue; color:white" | '''Johnny''' |- | こんばんは [[Image:Blue ball.png|10px|konbanWA]] |- | ''Good evening'' |- |- | ***<small> '''Same WARNING as the one above.''' </small> |- |} [[Image:Wikibooksqsjapanese1-snd006.ogg|left]]
Nice. But what about if Johnny and Mary meet and they want to know how each other are doing? Pretty easy, let's listen in.
[[Image:Qsjapaneseicon-man01.png|left]] {| align="left" | style="background:blue; color:white" | '''Johnny''' |- | '''げんき'''ですか？ [[Image:Blue ball.png|10px|genki desu ka?]] |- | ''Are you OK?'' |- |} [[Image:Wikibooksqsjapanese1-snd007.ogg|left]]
[[Image:Qsjapaneseicon-woman.png|right]] {| align="right" | style="background:red; color:white" | '''Mary''' |- | はい、'''げんき'''です. [[Image:Blue ball.png|10px|hai, genki desu]] |- | ''Yes, I'm fine.'' |- |} [[Image:Wikibooksqsjapanese1-snd008.ogg|right]]
{| align="center" | style="background:green; color:white" | '''～ Language note of interest! ～''' |- | げんき literally means something like ''base of your spirit/mood'' so people |- | speaking Japanese are asking if you have vigor or energy or something. |- | But "Are you vigorous? Yes, I am." just doesn't translate right! |- |}
* '''Next:''' [[empty link]]

So what do you do first? You get to know people! Lets meet some of the characters who will study with us. This is Johnny and Mary, they are just meeting each other now.
[[Image:Qsjapaneseicon-man01.png|left]]
{| align="left" | style="background:blue; color:white" | '''Johnny''' |- | はじめまして [[Image:Blue ball.png|10px|hajimemashite]] |- | ''Nice to meet you'' |- |} [[Image:Wikibooksqsjapanese1-snd001.ogg|left]]
That's nice. Now Mary wants to meet Johnny!
[[Image:Qsjapaneseicon-woman.png|right]] {| align="right" | style="background:red; color:white" | '''Mary''' |- | はじめまして、'''まり'''です [[Image:Blue ball.png|10px|Hajimemashite, mari desu.]] |- | ''Nice to meet you, I'm Mary.'' |- |} [[Image:Wikibooksqsjapanese1-snd002.ogg|right]]
[[Image:Qsjapaneseicon-man01.png|left]] {| align="left" | style="background:blue; color:white" | '''Johnny''' |- | よろしくおねがいします [[Image:Blue ball.png|10px|Yoroshiku onegaishimasu]] |- | ''Please be nice to me (polite)'' |- |}
[[Image:Wikibooksqsjapanese1-snd003.ogg|left]]
{| align="center" | style="background:green; color:white" | '''～ Language note of interest! ～''' |- | As with most things in any culture, these phrases are highly stylized |- | and are quite hard to literally translate. Don't worry about |- | what they "mean in English"! Just focus on the timing of it all. |- |}
Great! So let's move on to greeting people at different times of the day.
* '''Next: ''' [[empty link]]

There are many ways to say goodbye in any language. Both formal ways and friendly relaxed ways. Johnny seems like he is kind of rigid, but Mary wants to relax!
[[Image:Qsjapaneseicon-man01.png|left]] {| align="left" | style="background:blue; color:white" | '''Johnny''' |- | さようなら [[Image:Blue ball.png|10px|sayounara]] |- | ''Goodbye'' |- | <small>NOTE: This is formal, when you wont </small> |- | <small>see the person for awhile.</small> |- |} [[Image:Wikibooksqsjapanese1-snd009.ogg|left]]
Mary disregards the polite speech of Johnny and throws out a casual: [[Image:Qsjapaneseicon-woman.png|right]] {| align="right" | style="background:red; color:white" | '''Mary''' |- | またね. [[Image:Blue ball.png|10px|matane]] |- | ''See you.'' |- |} [[Image:Wikibooksqsjapanese1-snd010.ogg|right]]
Johnny can't shake his desire for formal language and before he goes away, he shares:
[[Image:Qsjapaneseicon-man01.png|left]] {| align="left" | style="background:blue; color:white" | '''Johnny''' |- | またあいましょう. [[Image:Blue ball.png|10px|mata aimasyou]] |- | ''Let's meet again.'' |- | <small>NOTE: The また in both of these </small> |- | <small>means simply "again".</small> |- |} [[Image:Wikibooksqsjapanese1-snd011.ogg|left]]
{| align="center" | style="background:green; color:white" | '''～ Language note of interest! ～''' |- | またね is just one variation of the way people casually say "see you" |- | when speaking Japanese. You might hear じゃ、またね or またあした |- | (that's literally "again tomorrow") or simply また！ |- |}
OK! Done with the first chunk. Now it's on to some real sentences.
* '''Next:''' [[empty link]]

revision.comment: tab says Purge now instead of p
revision.text: '''Add purge tab:''' This will give you a '''Purge''' tab on content pages to purge the server cache. This is useful for refreshing pages which do not show recent changes due to caching. [[Category:Wikibooks tools|Add purge tab]]

OK. So before we can have a conversation. We need to brake a sentence down.
<center> '''<big><font color="blue">これ</font><font color="red">は</font><font color="green">なん</font><font color="purple">です</font><font color="orange">か</font>'''
'''<font color="green">What</font> <font color="red">is</font> <font color="blue">this</font><font color="orange">?</font> <font color="purple">(polite)</font></big>''' </center>
{| align="center" | style="background:teal; color:white" | '''～ Important language notes! ～''' |- | は <small>(read this time as wa)</small> is an article that gives focus to this sentence. |- | Don't worry about it yet. You can learn grammar stuff later. |- | なん means ''what'', although by it's self it is なに. Words need to be polite |- | so when next to a thing or description use です (not with action words!) |- | Notice the か is a question mark, without it we have a normal sentence. |}
Lets listen to Johnny and Mary talk about stuff. Notice how the sentences change when they are talking about different things. You'll be able to plug-in your own new words too! Johnny and Mary are at a restaurant, what will they talk about?
[[Image:Qsjapaneseicon-man01.png|left]] {| align="left" | style="background:blue; color:white" | '''Johnny''' |- | これはなんですか？ [[Image:Blue ball.png|10px|kore WA nan desuka?]] |- | ''What's this?'' |- |} [[Image:Wikibooksqsjapanese1-snd012.ogg|left]]
[[Image:Qsjapaneseicon-woman.png|right]] {| align="right" | style="background:red; color:white" | '''Mary''' |- | '''それ'''は'''たべもの'''です. [[Image:Blue ball.png|10px|sore WA tabemono desu]] |- | ''That's food.'' |- |} [[Image:Wikibooksqsjapanese1-snd013.ogg|right]]
{| align="center" | style="background:orange; color:white" | '''Plug-in words:''' |- | あれ that over there |- | ここ here, そこ there, あそこ over there |- | えき train station, がっこう school |- | のみもの drink |- | びーる beer, みず water, ねこ cat, いぬ dog |- | <small>NOTE: The little <big>っ</big> like you see here </small> |- | <small>is always silent. It's a pause like the ' mark in I'm.</small> |}
Can you figure out how to plug-in these words? Let's look at a few examples from when Johnny met Mary suddenly by accident.
[[Image:Qsjapaneseicon-man01.png|left]] {| align="left" | style="background:blue; color:white" | '''Johnny''' |- | こんにちは.ここはとうきょう'''えき'''ですか？ [[Image:Blue ball.png|10px|konnichiWA. koko WA toukyou eki desuka?]] |- | ''Good afternoon. Is this Tokyo '''station'''?'' |- |} [[Image:Wikibooksqsjapanese1-snd014.ogg|left]]
Wow. That Johnny! He jumps right into the question right away. Well Mary?
[[Image:Qsjapaneseicon-woman.png|right]] {| align="right" | style="background:red; color:white" | '''Mary''' |- | はい,そうです.それはびーるですか？ [[Image:Blue ball.png|10px|hai, sou desu. sore WA bi-ru desu ka?]] |- | ''Yes, it is. Is that a beer?'' |- |} [[Image:Wikibooksqsjapanese1-snd015.ogg|right]]
{| align="center" | style="background:teal; color:white" | '''～ Important language note! ～''' |- | そう does not mean ''it is'' literally. It means something like |- | "that way" so with the polite marker です it means |- | "It is that way" or a basic way to confirm something. |}
Wow, is Johnny bringing beer with him into Tokyo station?
[[Image:Qsjapaneseicon-man01.png|left]] {| align="left" | style="background:blue; color:white" | '''Johnny''' |- | いいえ. これはみずです. [[Image:Blue ball.png|10px|iie. kore WA mizu desu]] |- | ''No. This is water.'' |- |} [[Image:Wikibooksqsjapanese1-snd016.ogg|left]]
Oh! It's only water. But what if they want to ask about action? Easy!
{| align="center" | style="background:orange; color:white" | '''Plug-in words:''' |- | いきます go |- | のみます drink (action) |- | います exist (living) |- | あります exist (not living) |- | たべます eat |- | いいます say |- | <small>NOTE: The <big>ます</big> make these words polite </small> |- | <small>so they do NOT need です.</small> |}
[[Image:Qsjapaneseicon-man01.png|left]] {| align="left" | style="background:blue; color:white" | '''Johnny''' |- | みずをのみますか？ [[Image:Blue ball.png|10px|mizu O nomimasu ka?]] |- | ''Will you drink water?'' |- | <small>NOTE: を is read as "o" and it is </small> |- | <small>just some grammar referring to an object, </small> |- | <small>don't worry. Just use it in this frame. </small> |- | <small>Also keep in mind this tense can be </small> |- | <small>''' will''' or '''are you'''!</small> |- |} [[Image:Wikibooksqsjapanese1-snd017.ogg|left]]
What will Mary say?
[[Image:Qsjapaneseicon-woman.png|right]] {| align="right" | style="background:red; color:white" | '''Mary''' |- | はい！それをのみます. [[Image:Blue ball.png|10px|hai! sore O nomimasu.]] |- | ''Yes. I'll drink that.'' |- |} [[Image:Wikibooksqsjapanese1-snd018.ogg|right]]
Gross! No cups! You'll get cooties, Mary! Oh well. Time to move to the next part!
* '''Next:''' [[empty link]]
'''Edit top section:''' this will add a link in the top right corner to edit the top section (the section before the first section heading). [[Category:Wikibooks tools|Edit top section]]

revision.comment: reword; no longer shows for non-admins
revision.text: '''Autodelete links:''' This script makes speedy deletion faster and easier. Once you install it, [[Special:Contributions]], [[Special:Newpages]], [[Special:Log]] and any viewed or preview will have an ''autodelete'' tab. By clicking that, you will be prompted for a summary. Once you click OK after the summary, all links will autodelete when clicked. If you leave the delete reason blank, the default is "per [[WB:SPEEDY|speedy deletion policy]]." [[Category:Wikibooks tools|Autodelete links]]

== Welcome message ==
Hello, and '''[[Wikibooks:Welcome, newcomers|welcome]]''' to [[Wikibooks]]!
Here are some tips to [[Help|help]] you get started: * To learn the wiki-markup-language syntax, see [[Help:Editing]]. * Make sure to sign your posts and comments with four tildes, like this: ~~~~ **There is a box at the top of the edit window (if javascript is enabled on your browser) that will insert it too (looks like part of a signature). This will let others know who left it, and make it easy to reply back to you. * Remember to conduct any editing experiments in the [[Wikibooks:Sandbox|sandbox]]. * You can tell the community something about yourself in your userpage. ** You can get to this page by clicking the tab at the top of the page labeled with your registered username. * Wikibooks is a collection of open-source textbooks. ([[WB:WIW|What is Wikibooks]]). * If you are a '''Wikipedian''', see [[Wikibooks:Wikibooks for Wikipedians]] for a primer on how things work here (it's a little different). ** If you want to base your work here on materials from Wikipedia, please use [[WB:RFI]] (requests for importation) to bring the material over in compliance with the GFDL. * If you're an '''instructor''' and plan on using Wikibooks for a class project, see [[Wikibooks:Guidelines for class projects]] * Please say hello at the [[Wikibooks:Reading room|Reading Room]] with any questions or ideas. * Eventually, you might want to read the [[Wikibooks:Manual of Style|Manual of Style]] and [[Wikibooks:Policies and guidelines|Policies and Guidelines]]. ** Help us by participating in policy and guideline creation. ** Please take a look at [[Wikibooks:Naming policy]] before starting a new book. * Remember to maintain a [[Wikibooks:Neutral point of view|Neutral point of view]]. * Explore, [[Wikibooks:Be bold in updating pages|be bold in editing pages]], and have fun!
You will find more resources in [[Wikibooks:Community Portal|Community Portal]]. If you want to ask a question, visit the [[Wikibooks:Study help desk|Study help desk]], the [[Wikibooks:Reading room|Reading Room]], [[Wikibooks:IRC channels|IRC channel]] or [[User_talk:Panic2k4|ask me personally on my talk page]]. For site news, see the [[WB:BB|Bulletin board]]. It might be a good idea to add that page to your "[[Special:Watchlist|watchlist]]" so that you can see when any new information is posted there. You can do that by clicking the tab labeled "watch" at the top of the page.
Good luck! --[[User:Panic2k4|Panic]] ([[User talk:Panic2k4|talk]]) 18:20, 18 December 2007 (UTC)

([[w:Wikipedia:Twinkle/doc#Configuration|Configuration]] goes in your [[Special:MyPage/skin.js|user JavaScript]]) [[Category:Wikibooks tools|Revert using Twinkle]]

revision.comment: rollbackers and patrollers can use some of these too
revision.text: For users with extra rights

==Welcome!== [[Help:Welcome, newcomers|Welcome to Wikibooks]], a collection of open-content textbooks! You don't have to [[Special:Userlogin|log in]] to read or edit articles on Wikibooks, but creating an account is quick, free and non-intrusive, requires no personal information, and gives you many benefits, including: *The use of a username of your choice *The ability to view all your contributions via a "My contributions" link *Your own [[wikipedia:user page|user page]] *Your own talk page which, if you choose, also allows users to send you messages without knowing your e-mail address *The use of your own personal [[Special:Watchlist|watchlist]] to which you can add articles that interest you *The ability to rename pages. *The ability to [[Special:Upload|upload images]] *The ability to customize the appearance and behavior of the website *The eligibility to become an [[Help:Administrators|administrator]] *The right to be heard in votes and elections *Your IP address will no longer be visible to other users.
We hope that you choose to become a Wikibookian and '''[[Special:Userlogin|create an account]]'''. Feel free to ask me any questions you may have on my talk page. By the way, make sure to sign your posts and comments with four tildes ('''~~~~'''), which will let others know who left it.
 '''– [[User:Mike.lifeguard|<font color="Indigo">Mike.lifeguard</font>]]''' | <sup>[[User talk:Mike.lifeguard|<font color="Indigo">talk</font>]]</sup> 19:38, 18 December 2007 (UTC)
{{Babel|de|en-3|fr-1}}

{{mbox|type=serious|msg='''Please do not make inappropriate edits to Wikibooks.'''
Edits that you have made have been considered inappropriate or even disruptive by your fellow contributors. Please use the [[Wikibooks:Sandbox|sandbox]] in the future if you wish to test something out. For a description of the type of content that we do allow, see [[WB:WIW]]. If you have questions about this, or need help, ask at the [[WB:HELP|Reading Room Assistance]] page.  '''– [[User:Mike.lifeguard|Mike.lifeguard]]''' | [[User talk:Mike.lifeguard|talk]] 19:56, 18 December 2007 (UTC)}}

{{#ifeq:"{{NAMESPACE}}"|"User talk"| Hello and '''[[Wikibooks:Welcome, newcomers|welcome]]''' to [[Wikibooks]], a collection of open-content textbooks! You should really consider [[Special:Userlogin|creating an account or login in]]. Here are some advantages: * The use of a username of your choice. * Greater security and privacy, your IP address will be hidden from most users. * You get your own personal user page and talk page, instead of having to share it. * [[Special:Contributions/{{PAGENAME}}|Your contributions]] will be recognized as your own, and not confused with anyone elses. * The use of your own watchlist which shows when pages you are interested in have changed. * Your opinions carry greater weight in the [[Wikibooks:Decision making|decision making process]]. * You become a recognized member of the Wikibooks community. * Creating an account is easy and only takes a few minutes of your time. We hope that you choose to become a [[Wikibooks:Wikibookians|Wikibookian]] and [[Special:Userlogin|create an account]].
Feel free to ask any questions on my talk page or in the [[Wikibooks:Reading room|Reading room]].
Be sure to sign your posts and comments on talk pages with four tildes (~~~~), this will let other editors know you said it.
|
'''This template must only be used on User talk pages.'''
}} '''– [[User:Mike.lifeguard|Mike.lifeguard]]''' | [[User talk:Mike.lifeguard|talk]] 20:16, 18 December 2007 (UTC)

== Welcome message ==
Hello, and '''[[Wikibooks:Welcome, newcomers|welcome]]''' to [[Wikibooks]]!
Here are some tips to [[Help|help]] you get started: * To learn the wiki-markup-language syntax, see [[Help:Editing]]. * Make sure to sign your posts and comments with four tildes, like this: ~~~~ **There is a box at the top of the edit window (if javascript is enabled on your browser) that will insert it too (looks like part of a signature). This will let others know who left it, and make it easy to reply back to you. * Remember to conduct any editing experiments in the [[Wikibooks:Sandbox|sandbox]]. * You can tell the community something about yourself in your userpage. ** You can get to this page by clicking the tab at the top of the page labeled with your registered username. * Wikibooks is a collection of open-source textbooks. ([[WB:WIW|What is Wikibooks]]). * If you are a '''Wikipedian''', see [[Wikibooks:Wikibooks for Wikipedians]] for a primer on how things work here (it's a little different). ** If you want to base your work here on materials from Wikipedia, please use [[WB:RFI]] (requests for importation) to bring the material over in compliance with the GFDL. * If you're an '''instructor''' and plan on using Wikibooks for a class project, see [[Wikibooks:Guidelines for class projects]] * Please say hello at the [[Wikibooks:Reading room|Reading Room]] with any questions or ideas. * Eventually, you might want to read the [[Wikibooks:Manual of Style|Manual of Style]] and [[Wikibooks:Policies and guidelines|Policies and Guidelines]]. ** Help us by participating in policy and guideline creation. ** Please take a look at [[Wikibooks:Naming policy]] before starting a new book. * Remember to maintain a [[Wikibooks:Neutral point of view|Neutral point of view]]. * Explore, [[Wikibooks:Be bold in updating pages|be bold in editing pages]], and have fun!
You will find more resources in [[Wikibooks:Community Portal|Community Portal]]. If you want to ask a question, visit the [[Wikibooks:Study help desk|Study help desk]], the [[Wikibooks:Reading room|Reading Room]], [[Wikibooks:IRC channels|IRC channel]] or [[User_talk:Panic2k4|ask me personally on my talk page]]. For site news, see the [[WB:BB|Bulletin board]]. It might be a good idea to add that page to your "[[Special:Watchlist|watchlist]]" so that you can see when any new information is posted there. You can do that by clicking the tab labeled "watch" at the top of the page.
Good luck! --[[User:Panic2k4|Panic]] ([[User talk:Panic2k4|talk]]) 23:10, 18 December 2007 (UTC)

== Join Us! == {{#ifeq:"{{NAMESPACE}}"|"User talk"| Hello and '''[[Wikibooks:Welcome, newcomers|welcome]]''' to [[Wikibooks]], a collection of open-content textbooks! You should really consider [[Special:Userlogin|creating an account or login in]]. Here are some advantages: * The use of a username of your choice. * Greater security and privacy, your IP address will be hidden from most users. * You get your own personal user page and talk page, instead of having to share it. * [[Special:Contributions/{{PAGENAME}}|Your contributions]] will be recognized as your own, and not confused with anyone elses. * The use of your own watchlist which shows when pages you are interested in have changed. * Your opinions carry greater weight in the [[Wikibooks:Decision making|decision making process]]. * You become a recognized member of the Wikibooks community. * Creating an account is easy and only takes a few minutes of your time. We hope that you choose to become a [[Wikibooks:Wikibookians|Wikibookian]] and [[Special:Userlogin|create an account]].
Feel free to ask any questions on my talk page or in the [[Wikibooks:Reading room|Reading room]].
Be sure to sign your posts and comments on talk pages with four tildes (~~~~), this will let other editors know you said it.
|

revision.text:
{{WMOG-header|Matricaria discoidea}}{{Hortibox|Pineappleweed | Image = Matricaria discoidea.JPG | Binomial = Matricaria discoidea | Genus = | Family = Asteraceae | Variety = | Type = | Sun = | Water = | Soil = | USDA Hardiness Zone = | Sunset Zone = | Propagation = | Pruning season = | Pruning tolerance = | Forcing = | Transplant = | Pest issues = | Disease issues = | Bloom season = | Fruit season = | Sowing methods = | Harvest = | Storage = | Weediness = weedy | Pollination = | Seed Dispersal = | Germination Time = | Germination Signal = | Ripe Seed = | Seed Banking = | Vegetative Spread = | Allelopathy = | Group = | Sowing time = | Days to germination = | Days to baby = | Days to maturity = | Bolting = | Flat cropping = | Planting depth = | Plant spacing = | Row spacing = | Seed collection = | Height and spread = | Root = | Growth rate = | Shade cast = | Underplanting = | Toxicity and edibility = | Patent= | Hybrid type= }} '''''Matricaria discoidea''''', commonly known as '''pineapple weed''' is an annual plant native to North America and NE Asia but which has become a cosmopolitan weed. According to ITIS the specific name is ''Matricaria discoidea'' DC, but many synonyms are in the literature, including ''M. matricarioides'', ''M. suaveolens'', and ''Chamomilla suaveolens''.
==Description== The flower head is cone-shaped, composed of dense-packed yellowish-green corollas, and lacking ray-florets. The leaves are pinnately dissected and sweet-scented when crushed. The plant grows 3 to 12 inches (7.5 - 30 cm) high.
==Growing Conditions== The plant grows well in disturbed areas, especially those with poor, compacted soil. It can be seen blooming on footpaths, roadsides, and similar places in spring and early summer. In the USA, it can be found from central Alaska down to California and all the way to Maine.
==Varieties==
<!--general discussion or bulleted list-->
==Uses== The flowers exude a chamomile/pineapple aroma when crushed. They are edible and have been used in salads (although they may become bitter by the time the plant blooms) and to make a herbal tea [http://www.nps.gov/klgo/flora/pineappleweed.htm][http://www.arthurleej.com/a-pineapple.html].
Pineapple weed has been used for medicinal purposes, including for relief of gastrointestinal upset, infected sores, fevers, and postpartum anemia <ref>http://herb.umd.umich.edu/herb/search.pl?searchstring=Matricaria+discoidea</ref>.
==Maintenance==
<!--discuss any special maintenance concerns, such as pruning, transplanting, monitoring, etc.-->
==Propagation==
<!--discuss propagation-->
==Harvest==
<!--Discuss harvesting and storage-->
==Pests and Diseases==
==References== <references/> * Robbins, W. W., Margaret K. Bellue, and Walter S. Ball. 1970. ''Weeds of California''. Documents and Publications, Sacramento. 547 p. * Gregory L. Tilford. 1997. ''Edible and Medicinal Plants of the West''. Mountain Press Publishing Company, Missoula. 110 p. * [http://www.ipm.ucdavis.edu/PMG/WEEDS/pineapple_weed.html University of California], Statewide Integrated Pest Management Program * [http://linnaeus.nrm.se/flora/di/astera/matri/matrmatv.jpg Den virtuella floran: ''Matricaria discoidea'' distribution]

revision.comment: Set stable version settings for "Wikijunior:World War II/Joseph Stalin" [Default: Stable, Precedence: Pristine]
revision.text:
== Quick Facts == *'''Full name:''' Iosif Vissarionovich Dzhugashvili *'''Adopted name:''' Joseph Stalin *'''Born:''' 18 December 1878 [[image:JStalin_Secretary_general_CCCP_1942.jpg| thumb|225px| right]] *'''Died:''' 5 March 1953 *'''Leader of:''' The Soviet Union
[[image:Teheran conference-1943.jpg| thumb|225px| right]]
Stalin was General Secretary of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union's Central Committee from 1922 until his death in 1953. This meant he was the leader of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics ("USSR"), which was also called the Soviet Union. That country doesn't exist any more. It was made up of a large number of other countries like Russia, Ukraine, Estonia, Latvia and Georgia. In many ways he was very similar to Hitler - an absolute dictator.
The USSR was created in 1919 after the end of the Russian Civil War. Stalin became leader of the USSR after its first leader, Vladimir Lenin, died in 1924. Stalin tried to turn the USSR into a "communist" state. His ideas sometimes worked but sometimes went wrong. His plan to change the way crops were grown is believed by some to have lead to the death of up to 6 million people.
Then, in the 1930s, Stalin began to kill his enemies and rivals. He executed millions of his own people. These included many army officers and other people he saw as threat to his power. This greatly weakened the Soviet army. Although it was huge and well armed, its officers were very new and were scared of being shot if they seemed to be clever. They were at a loss as to how to fight the clever and experienced German army.
Before the war, Stalin did a deal with Germany and they both agreed to invade Poland. He thought that Germany wouldn't attack the USSR as they had made this deal. In fact, some historians think Stalin was planning to invade Germany but the Germans attacked first! Anyway, Germany did attack and to start with it looked like the Germans would win easily, but Stalin was ruthless. He was willing to sacrifice any number of soldiers to stop the Germans capturing important machinery (like tank factories) and to slow their advance on the capital, Moscow. Despite millions of deaths, this worked and in the end the USSR beat the Germans.
It might have ended differently if Hitler hadn't made mistakes. Many people in the USSR welcomed the Germans as "liberators". They had been living with Stalin and his "purges", where he killed those he didn't trust. Many people, especially outside of Russia, might have joined the war on the German side. But Hitler didn't want their help, and by being even more cruel than Stalin and killing even more of them, turned them against the Germans.
{{BookCat}}

== location of the merge discussion ==
It would be nice if a merge discussion occurred in one place -- rather than half the discussion on the "mergefrom" talk page, and the other half on the "mergeto" talk page.
Wikipedia is set up so that, when someone slaps a "mergefrom" tag on a page, a message like "Please discuss whether or not this merge should happen on the discussion page." shows up on the page. Clicking that "discussion" link goes to that article's own discussion page -- just like clicking the "discussion" tab.
When someone slaps a "mergeto" tag on a page, a similar-seeming message like "Please discuss whether or not this merge should happen on the discussion page." shows up on the page also. However, on Wikipedia, when I click that "discussion" link, I don't go to talk page of the article with the "mergeto" tag. Instead, it goes to the other article's discussion page -- the article mentioned by the mergeto tag.
Could someone fix this tag so it acts the way a Wikipedian would expect? Or is there some reason for Wikibooks to be different? --[[User:DavidCary|DavidCary]] ([[User talk:DavidCary|talk]]) 02:32, 19 December 2007 (UTC)
:What would be your preference? Should the discussion occur on the "to" page, or the "from" page. I'll gladly make the change (it's a good idea) once we know where the discussion should take place. --'''Whiteknight''' ([[User:Whiteknight|Page]]) ([[User talk:Whiteknight|Talk]]) 02:52, 19 December 2007 (UTC)
:: My preference is to do it the way Wikipedia does it. Currently this "mergeto" template links to the discussion page of the module it is placed *on*. I would prefer this "mergeto" template to, instead, link to the "other" discussion page. (Currently the "{{tl|mergefrom}}" template also links to the discussion page of the module it is placed *on*. Keep that template the same -- so the merge discussion occurs in that one discussion page). --[[User:DavidCary|DavidCary]] ([[User talk:DavidCary|talk]]) 03:46, 6 January 2008 (UTC)
That much makes good sense. Let me change around the links now, and hope nobody complains. --'''Whiteknight''' ([[User:Whiteknight|Page]]) ([[User talk:Whiteknight|Talk]]) 00:07, 7 January 2008 (UTC)
I am Hesperian on various other Wikimedia projects. I have no immediate plans to use this account.

[[User:Cilantrohead|Cilantrohead]] ([[User talk:Cilantrohead|talk]]) 22:20, 1 March 2008 (UTC) == Usurp request == Hello, I am a bureaucrat at the English Wikibooks. You had registered the username Mmh, but have made *3 edits, and *0 log entries. Since you are inactive at Wikibooks, we are considering giving your username to someone else who uses that username on other wikis. To do this, we will change your username to Mmh (usurped). If you return to Wikibooks you are of course welcome to change your username again to just about anything you like. We do this to allow active users to have the same username on all the wikis we operate. If you do not want us to change your username, please respond within 7 days of this email, and we will discuss possible compromises. Thanks  '''— [[User:Mike.lifeguard|Mike.lifeguard]]''' | [[User talk:Mike.lifeguard|talk]] 01:10, 3 April 2009 (UTC)

revision.comment: [[WB:REVERT|Reverted]] edits by [[Special:Contributions/62.253.210.146|62.253.210.146]] ([[User talk:62.253.210.146|talk]]) to last version by Morphypnos
revision.text:
A sensor is a device which converts a physical property into an electrical property (such as resistance). A sensing system is a system (usually a circuit) which allows this electrical property, and so the physical property, to be measured.
==Temperature Sensor==
[[Image:Thermistor_potential_divider.svg|right|thumb|200px|Use of a potential divider and thermistor to measure temperature]] A common example of a sensing system is a temperature sensor in a thermostat, which uses a thermistor. In the most common type of thermistor (an NTC), the resistance decreases as the temperature increases. This effect is achieved by making the thermistor out of a semiconductor. The thermistor is then used in a potential divider, as in the diagram on the right. In this diagram, the potential difference is divided between the resistor and the thermistor. As the temperature rises, the resistance of the thermistor decreases, so the potential difference across it decreases. This means that potential difference across the resistor increases as temperature increases. This is why the voltmeter is across the resistor, not the thermistor.
==Properties==
There are three main properties of sensing systems you need to know about:
===Sensitivity===
This is the amount of change in voltage output per. unit change in input (the physical property). For example, in the above sensing system, if the voltage on the voltmeter increased by 10V as the temperature increased by 6.3°C:
<math>S = \frac{10}{6.3} \approx 1.59</math> V/°C
===Resolution===
This is the smallest change in the physical property detectable by the sensing system. Sometimes, the limiting factor is the number of decimal places the voltmeter can display. So if, for example, the voltmeter can display the voltage to 2 decimal places, the smallest visible change in voltage is 0.01V. We can then use the sensitivity of the sensor to calculate the resolution.
<math>S = 1.59 = \frac{0.01}{R}</math>
<math>R = \frac{0.01}{1.59} \approx 0.006</math>°C
===Response Time===
This is the time the sensing system takes to display a change in the physical property it is measuring. It is often difficult to measure.
==Signal Amplification==
Sometimes, a sensing system gives a difference in output voltage, but the sensitivity is far too low to be of any use. There are two solutions to this problem, which can be used together:
===Amplification===
An amplifier can be placed in the system, increasing the signal. The main problem with this is that the signal cannot exceed the maximum voltage of the system, so values will be chopped off of the top and bottom of the signal because it is so high.
===Wheatstone Bridge===
[[Image:Wheatstone_bridge.svg|left|thumb|200px|A wheatstone bridge, using a thermistor]] This solution is far better, especially when used prior to amplification. Instead of using just one pair of resistors, a second pair is used, and the potential difference between the two pairs (which are connected in parallel) is measured. This means that, if, at the sensing resistor (e.g. thermistor / LDR) the resistance is at its maximum, a signal of 0V is produced. This means that the extremes of the signal are not chopped off, making for a much better sensor.
==Questions==
An LDR's resistance decreases from a maximum resistance of 2kΩ to a minimum resistance of 0Ω as light intensity increases. It is used in a distance sensing system which consists of a 9V power supply, a 1.6 kΩ resistor, the LDR and a multimeter which displays voltage to 2 decimal places measuring the potential difference across one of the two resistors.
1. Across which resistor should the multimeter be connected in order to ensure that, as the distance from the light source to the sensor increases, the potential difference recorded increases?
2. In complete darkness, what voltage is recorded on the multimeter?
3. When a light source moves 0.5m away from the sensor, the voltage on the multimeter increases by 2V. What is the sensitivity of the sensing system when using this light source, in V m<sup>-1</sup>?
4. When the same light source is placed 0m from the sensor, the potential difference is 0V. When the light source is 1m away, what voltage is displayed on the multimeter?
5. What is the resolution of the sensing system?
6. Draw a circuit diagram showing a similar sensing system to this, using a Wheatstone bridge and amplifier to improve the sensitivity of the system.
7. What is the maximum potential difference that can reach the amplifier using this new system (ignore the amplification)?
8. If this signal were to be amplified 3 times, would it exceed the maximum voltage of the system? What would the limits on the signal be?
[[/Worked Solutions/]] [[Category:{{BOOKNAME}}|{{SUBPAGENAME}}]]

revision.comment: [[A Wikimanual of Gardening/Myosotis]] moved to [[Horticulture/Myosotis]]: Robot: moved page
revision.text:
{{WMOG-header|Myosotis}}{{Hortibox|Forget-me-nots | Image = Forget-me-not closeup 2005 01.jpg | Binomial = | Genus = Myosotis | Family = | Variety = | Type = | Sun = | Water = | Soil = | USDA Hardiness Zone = | Sunset Zone = | Propagation = | Pruning season = | Pruning tolerance = | Forcing = | Transplant = | Pest issues = | Disease issues = | Bloom season = | Fruit season = | Sowing methods = | Harvest = | Storage = | Weediness = | Pollination = | Seed Dispersal = | Germination Time = | Germination Signal = | Ripe Seed = | Seed Banking = | Vegetative Spread = | Allelopathy = | Group = | Sowing time = | Days to germination = | Days to baby = | Days to maturity = | Bolting = | Flat cropping = | Planting depth = | Plant spacing = | Row spacing = | Seed collection = | Height and spread = | Root = | Growth rate = | Shade cast = | Underplanting = | Toxicity and edibility = | Patent= | Hybrid type= }} The '''Forget-me-nots''' are flowering plants in the family Boraginaceae, grown for their long-lasting blue flowers.
There are about 50 species in the genus, and among them there is considerable variation. Nevertheless a considerable number of the species fit the same description, of a small (1 cm diameter or less) rather flat 5-petalled blue flower growing profusely on straggly stems, flowering in spring. Colour variation is somewhat frequent within species, and white or pink forms are quite likely to be seen. They are popular in gardens, and cultivated forms often show a mixture of colours. The forget-me-nots need shade, not sun.
They are widely distributed. Most Myosotis species are endemic to New Zealand, though one or two European species, especially the Wood Forget-me-not, ''[[../Myosotis sylvatica/]]'' have been introduced in most of the temperate regions of Europe, Asia and America. ''[[../Myosotis scorpioides/]]'' is also known as ''scorpion grass''.
The name was borrowed from Old French "ne m'oubliez pas" and first used in English in c.1532. Loans and translations of it can be found in most European and some non-European languages, like German "Vergissmeinnicht", Italian "Nontiscordardimé", Polish "Niezapominajka", Slovak "Nezábudky", Danish "Forglem-mig-ej", Swedish "Förgätmigej", Dutch "vergeet-mij-nietje", Spanish "no-me-olvides", Russian "Незабудки", Bulgarian “Незабравки”, Lithuanian "Neužmirštuolės", Greek "Μη με λησμονείς" (also connected to the people who died during the 1974 events in Cyprus), Esperanto "neforgesumino", Chinese "勿忘草" (wu wang cao), Korean "물망초" (勿忘草, mul mang cho), Japanese "勿忘草" (Wasurenagusa), Hebrew "זכריני" (Zichrini), Persian "فراموشم مکن" (farâmusham nakon), Hungarian "Nefelejts", Turkish "Unutma Beni" etc.
In the United States of America, the forget-me-not is the state flower of Alaska, precisely ''[[../Myosotis alpestris/]]''. The Forget-me-nots are traditionally worn by Newfoundlanders on July 1st in remembrance of those Newfoundlanders that died during the First World War. July 1 was chosen because of the high number of casualties suffered by the Royal Newfoundland Regiment on 1 July 1916 during the Battle of the Somme.
==Description== Forget-me-nots can be annual or perennial plants. Their root systems are generally diffuse. Their seeds are found in small, tulip shaped pods along the stem to the flower. The pods attach to clothing when brushed against and eventually fall off, leaving the small seed within to germinate elsewhere.
==Growing Conditions==
<!--sun, soil, etc.-->
==Selected species== * ''[[../Myosotis alpestris/]]'' - Alpine Forget-me-not * ''[[../Myosotis alpina/]]'' * ''[[../Myosotis arvensis/]]'' - Field Forget-me-not * ''[[../Myosotis australis/]]'' * ''[[../Myosotis azorica/]]'' * ''[[../Myosotis caespitosa/]]'' - Tufted Forget-me-not * ''[[../Myosotis colensoi/]]'' * ''[[../Myosotis discolor/]]'' - Changing Forget-me-not * ''[[../Myosotis ramosissima/]]'' - Early Forget-me-not * ''[[../Myosotis scorpioides/]]'' - Water Forget-me-not * ''[[../Myosotis secunda/]]'' - Creeping Forget-me-not * ''[[../Myosotis sicula/]]'' - Jersey Forget-me-not * ''[[../Myosotis sylvatica/]]'' - Wood Forget-me-not
==Uses==
<!--Ornamental uses, food crop, material use (lumber, cut flower), etc.-->
==Maintenance==
<!--discuss any special maintenance concerns, such as pruning, transplanting, monitoring, etc.-->
==Propagation== Seeds can be collected by putting a piece of paper under the stems and shaking them. The seed pods and some seeds will fall out.
==Harvest==
<!--Discuss harvesting and storage-->

{{commons|{{SUBPAGENAME}}}} {{wikiversity-bc|{{SUBPAGENAME}}}} {{Horticat (add "y" where applicable)| | taxa level (family, genus, species, variety) = genus | large tree = | small tree = | large shrub = | small shrub = | woody vine = | herbaceous vine = | herbaceous plant = y | herbaceous ground cover = | woody ground cover = | aquatic = | evergreen = | ephemeral = | spring flowers = | summer flowers = | fall flowers = | winter flowers = | weedy or agressive = | perennial = | annual = | biennial = | full shade = | part shade = | full sun = | drought tolerant = | wet soil tolerant = | quality nectar source = | attracts songbirds = | attracts hummingbirds = | attracts butterflies = | fruit or vegetable = | culinary herb = | edible flower = | medicinal uses = | good for cut flowers = | good for cut fruit = | good for dried cut flowers = | good fragrance = | pest and disease resistant = | deer resistant = | frequently deer browsed = | North America native = | North America invasive = | South America native = | South America invasive = | Europe native = | Europe invasive = | Asia native = | Asia invasive = | Africa native = | Africa invasive = | Australia native = | Australia invasive = | USDA 1 = | USDA 2 = | USDA 3 = | USDA 4 = | USDA 5 = | USDA 6 = | USDA 7 = | USDA 8 = | USDA 9 = | USDA 10 = | USDA 11 = | USDA 12 = | white flowers = | pink flowers = | red flowers = | orange flowers = | yellow flowers = | green flowers = | blue flowers = y | purple flowers = | brown flowers = | black flowers = | poisonous to humans = | poisonous to livestock or pets = | silver or gray leaves = | red or purple leaves = | yellow leaves = | blue leaves = | variegated white = | variegated yellow = | variegated multicolor = | horticat template version (used for robitic updates) = 7.12.13 }}

Note to the reader: I am not entirely happy with the answers given on this page. --[[User:Sjlegg|Sjlegg]] ([[User talk:Sjlegg|talk]]) 15:01, 19 December 2007 (UTC)
'''An LDR's resistance decreases from a maximum resistance of 2kΩ to a minimum resistance of 0Ω as light intensity increases. It is used in a distance sensing system which consists of a 9V power supply, a 1.6 kΩ resistor, the LDR and a multimeter which displays voltage to 2 decimal places measuring the potential difference across one of the two resistors.
'''1. Across which resistor should the multimeter be connected in order to ensure that, as the distance from the light source to the sensor increases, the potential difference recorded increases?'''
As light intensity increases, distance decreases. So, as distance increases, light intensity decreases. As light intensity decreases, the LDR's resistance increases, as does the potential difference across it. So, as distance increases, the potential difference increases. Since we want the potential difference to change in the same direction as the distance, the multimeter must go across the LDR, not the resistor.
'''2. In complete darkness, what voltage is recorded on the multimeter?'''
The voltage is split between the 1.6kΩ resistor and the LDR, which currently has a resistance of 2kΩ. Therefore, the potential difference across the LDR is:
<math>V = \frac{2}{2+1.6} \times 9 = 5V</math>
'''3. When a light source moves 0.5m away from the sensor, the voltage on the multimeter increases by 2V. What is the sensitivity of the sensing system when using this light source, in V m<sup>-1</sup>?'''
<math>S = \frac{2}{0.5} = 4\mbox{ Vm}^{-1}</math>
'''4. When the same light source is placed 0m from the sensor, the potential difference is 0V. When the light source is 1m away, what voltage is displayed on the multimeter?'''
Assuming a linear relationship between distance and potential difference, we know that:
<math>0.25 = \frac{m}{V}</math>
Hence:
<math>V = \frac{m}{0.25} = \frac{1}{0.25} = 4V</math>
'''5. What is the resolution of the sensing system?'''
The multimeter measures to 2 decimal places, so the smallest measurable voltage is 0.01V.
<math>0.25 = \frac{m}{V}</math>
Hence:
<math>m = 0.25 \times V = 0.25 \times 0.01 = 0.0025\mbox{ m} = 2.5\mbox{ mm}</math>
'''6. Draw a circuit diagram showing a similar sensing system to this, using a Wheatstone bridge and amplifier to improve the sensitivity of the system.'''
[[Image:Wheatstone_bridge_LDR_amp_correct.svg]]
'''7. What is the maximum potential difference that can reach the amplifier using this new system (ignore the amplification)?'''
The maximum potential difference will occur when the LDR has no resistance. This will result in 9V on the left-hand side of the voltmeter, and 5V on the right-hand side. The difference is 4V.
'''8. If this signal were to be amplified 3 times, would it exceed the maximum voltage of the system? What would the limits on the signal be?'''
<math>4 \times 3 = 12V > 9V</math>
The signal would be limited to the range -9V < V < 9V.
[[Category:{{FULLBOOKNAME}}|{{FULLCHAPTERNAME}}]]

{{commons|{{SUBPAGENAME}}}} {{wikiversity-bc|{{SUBPAGENAME}}}} {{Horticat (add "y" where applicable)| | taxa level (family, genus, species, variety) = species | large tree = | small tree = | large shrub = | small shrub = | woody vine = | herbaceous vine = | herbaceous plant = y | herbaceous ground cover = | woody ground cover = | aquatic = | evergreen = | ephemeral = | spring flowers = y | summer flowers = | fall flowers = | winter flowers = | weedy or agressive = | perennial = y | annual = | biennial = | full shade = | part shade = | full sun = | drought tolerant = y | wet soil tolerant = | quality nectar source = y | attracts songbirds = | attracts hummingbirds = | attracts butterflies = | fruit or vegetable = | culinary herb = | edible flower = | medicinal uses = | good for cut flowers = | good for cut fruit = | good for dried cut flowers = | good fragrance = | pest and disease resistant = | deer resistant = | frequently deer browsed = | North America native = y | North America invasive = | South America native = | South America invasive = | Europe native = | Europe invasive = | Asia native = | Asia invasive = | Africa native = | Africa invasive = | Australia native = | Australia invasive = | USDA 1 = | USDA 2 = | USDA 3 = | USDA 4 = | USDA 5 = | USDA 6 = y | USDA 7 = | USDA 8 = | USDA 9 = | USDA 10 = | USDA 11 = | USDA 12 = | white flowers = | pink flowers = | red flowers = | orange flowers = | yellow flowers = y | green flowers = | blue flowers = | purple flowers = | brown flowers = | black flowers = | poisonous to humans = | poisonous to livestock or pets = | silver or gray leaves = | red or purple leaves = | yellow leaves = | blue leaves = | variegated white = | variegated yellow = | variegated multicolor = | horticat template version (used for robitic updates) = 7.12.13 }}

{{WMOG-header|Paulownia tomentosa}}{{Hortibox|Princess Tree | Image = Paulownia tomentosa2.jpg | Binomial = Paulownia tomentosa | Genus = | Family = | Variety = | Type = Large tree | Sun = | Water = | Soil = | USDA Hardiness Zone = | Sunset Zone = | Propagation = | Pruning season = | Pruning tolerance = | Forcing = | Transplant = | Pest issues = | Disease issues = | Bloom season = | Fruit season = | Sowing methods = | Harvest = | Storage = | Weediness = | Pollination = | Seed Dispersal = | Germination Time = | Germination Signal = | Ripe Seed = | Seed Banking = | Vegetative Spread = | Allelopathy = | Group = | Sowing time = | Days to germination = | Days to baby = | Days to maturity = | Bolting = | Flat cropping = | Planting depth = | Plant spacing = | Row spacing = | Seed collection = | Height and spread = | Root = | Growth rate = | Shade cast = | Underplanting = | Toxicity and edibility = | Patent= | Hybrid type= }} '''''Paulownia tomentosa''''' (also known as the '''Empress Tree''', '''Princess Tree''' or '''Foxglove Tree'''; '''''pao tong 泡桐''''' in Chinese) is a deciduous flowering tree native to central and western China, but invasive in the US [http://plants.usda.gov/java/nameSearch?keywordquery=Paulownia+tomentosa&mode=sciname&submit.x=17&submit.y=12][http://nbii-nin.ciesin.columbia.edu/ipane/earlydetection/tables.htm][http://www.tneppc.org/TNEPPC2004PlantList-8x11.pdf].
==Description== It grows to 10-25 m tall, with large heart-shaped to five-lobed leaves 15-40 cm across, arranged in opposite pairs on the stem. On young growth, the leaves may be in whorls of three and be much bigger than the leaves on more mature growth ([http://www.cas.vanderbilt.edu/bioimages/species/pato2.htm#Whole%20tree image comparing large and small trees]). The characteristic large size of the young growth is exploited by gardeners : by [[../Pollarding|pollarding]] the tree and ensuring there is vigorous new growth every year, massive leaves are produced (up to 60cm across). These are popular in the modern style of gardening which uses large-foliaged and "architectural" plants. The flowers are produced before the leaves in early spring, on panicles 10-30 cm long, with a tubular purple corolla 4-6 cm long resembling a foxglove flower. The fruit is a dry egg-shaped capsule 3-4 cm long, containing numerous tiny seeds. The seeds are winged and disperse by wind and water. Pollarded trees do not produce flowers, as these only form on mature wood.
==Growing Conditions== Paulownia tomentosa can survive wildfire because the roots can regenerate new, very fast-growing stems. It is tolerant of pollution and it is not fussy about soil type. For this reason it functions ecologically as a pioneer plant. Its nitrogen-rich leaves provide good fodder and its roots prevent soil erosion. Eventually, ''Paulownia'' is succeeded by taller trees that shade it. It cannot thrive in the shade of other trees.
The soft, lightweight seeds were commonly used as a packing material by Chinese porcelain exporters in the 19th century, before the development of polystyrene packaging. Packing cases would often leak or burst open in transit and scatter the seeds along rail tracks. This, together with seeds released by specimens deliberately planted for ornament, has allowed the species to become an invasive weed tree in areas where the climate is suitable for its growth, notably Japan and the eastern United States.<ref>{{cite web | title=Princess tree | work=Plant Conservation Alliance's Alien Plant Working Group Least Wanted | url=http://www.nps.gov/plants/alien/fact/pato1.htm | author=Tom Remaley | date=2006-06-27}}</ref>
==Varieties==
<!--general discussion or bulleted list-->
==Uses== In China, an old custom is to plant an Empress Tree when a baby girl is born. The fast-growing tree matures when she does. When she is eligible for marriage the tree is cut down and carved into wooden articles for her dowry, and carving the wood of Paulownia is an art form in Japan and China.
==Maintenance==
<!--discuss any special maintenance concerns, such as pruning, transplanting, monitoring, etc.-->
==Propagation==
<!--discuss propagation-->
